1.title: The Rocking Chair
1.subtitle: Phase 1 (Meditation)
1.description:
The 20/20 Life Vision Challenge is a 30 step journey that could, if you let it, transform your life. I am Arman, and I will be your guide. Let’s start with a 5 minute meditation called,‘The Rocking Chair’. Get comfortable, put your phone on silent, turn off the TV, dim the lights and close your eyes. Play some soft music, if it helps you relax.

Ready? Now picture yourself in this rocking chair at 90 years old. You are with your grandchildren, reflecting on your life as the sun gracefully sets in the dis-tance. Your grandkids want to know about your life. What will you share with them?

Hear the waves softly coming to the shore. Keep your eyes closed and meditate deeply on this question: your life, what has it been? How will you tell this story to the next generation.
Now come back to present day and compare who you are right now, in relation to that 90-year-old man or woman whose eyes you just saw the world through for the last 5 minutes.
1.snippet: Review your best life memories, regrets and defining moments from the eyes of your future, 90-year-old self.

assignments.content: What are your best memories?
What are your main regrets?
What are your defining life moments (e.g., marriage, birth of a child, career awards etc.)?
What emotions do you feel as you reflect on your life as a 90-year-old?

2.title: How Do I Spend My Time?
2.subtitle: Phase 1 (Meditation)
2.description:
This exercise focuses on a more specific and immediate area of your life - life categories, however you define them.

What if you could wake up next week and spend your time doing whatever you really want to do? Think about your life right now, and what typical weekdays and weekends are like. How would you break down your life, in terms of categories? How much time do you estimate spending on each area in a given week (168 hours)? What specifically would you like to do more of? Less of? Who would you like to spend more time with? Less time with? Where would you like to spend more time, and less time?
2.stepScreenDescription: Things To Do More Or Less Of
2.snippet: Estimate your current (versus ideal) weekly time allocation across 168 hours (a full week).

assignments.content: Break down a typical 168 hour week by Life Category.
How many hours do you ideally want to spend in each activity?
What activities do you ideally want to engage in less?
What activities do you ideally want to engage in more?

3.title: What Are My Strengths & Weaknesses?
3.subtitle: Phase 1 (Meditation)
3.description:
The main goal of this exercise is to determine your best “natural resources” (or strengths) as well as your “road blocks” (or weaknesses). What has been hold-ing you back from reaching your full potential? Our vices can completely dis-rupt and ruin otherwise happy and fruitful lives. Now isn’t the time to focus only on the positives and brush character flaws under the rug. It is also quite rare to witness people living at their full potential. However, when you come across those who are at or close to that level, you can feel them beaming with energy, and see how happy – and effective – they are. Do you know someone like that? If so, take note for future role modeling exercises.

In the movie "Lucy", Morgan Freeman delivers a great lecture about what might happen if human beings start using more than 10% of our brains. I definitely rec-ommend watching it. Freeman notes that humans possess 100 billion neurons but only fifteen percent are activated. He goes on to say that "there are more connections in the human body than there are stars in the galaxy." Accordingly, "we possess a gigantic network of information to which we have almost no access.”

Can you be objective about your own strengths and weaknesses? Objectivity is one of the cornerstones of wisdom and maturity and it is one of the most diffi-cult qualities to possess. It requires us to see ourselves clearly; without bias and judgment – not an easy task. Ask yourself what kind of impression you make on people (not just the first impression, but over time). See yourself through the eyes of others who know you well enough to understand your life path so far.

Have the courage to be honest about yourself but don’t beat yourself up in the process. The concept of “brutal honesty” is just an excuse to be mean to people and put them down to make others feel better. So be gentle.
3.snippet: Think about your Strengths & Weaknesses and tie them to specific goals attained or not.

assignments.content: What are your strengths?
What are your weaknesses?
What does a close friend or family member, an objective one, think of your strengths and weaknesses?

4.title: Who Is on My Board of Advisors?
4.subtitle: Phase 1: Meditation
4.description:
This exercise begins the process of forming a Board of Advisors, either formally or informally - the CEO of Me concept. It is important to go beyond yourself and your ideas, and bring in others who know you well and are actively part of your life. Feedback and encouragement as we move along our life path is crucial.

You can learn a lot about yourself based on who you rely on and spend most of your time with. I’ve observed that many people do not have an effective and nurturing supporting cast. We go with the easy road, surrounding ourselves with familiar faces. Some are lucky enough to have at least one strong role model -  maybe a parent or a friend who collaborates on life’s trials and gives guidance.

With a little bit of effort, we can find new people or revive old relationships that are positive. Who are you comfortable talking to about your goals and deep-est desires?

Your challenge is to envision the ideal Board of Advisors for your life, a group that gives you the best chance of fulfilling your 20/20 Vision.
4.snippet: Comprise your supporting cast, the people who help you in various aspects of your life.

assignments.content: Who is on your Board of Advisors?
List any current or potential support groups and meetups, formal or informal, that are a source of positive energy for you, in one or more domains of life.

5.title: What Are my Life Goals?
5.subtitle: Phase 1: Meditation
5.description:
What kind of attitude and approach do you have towards goal setting and life goals? Do you not think about it much, just trying to make it through the days, taking things as they come? Or are you a go getter, a task master? In looking back at my goals over the years, I recognized the need for more classification, as there are vastly different types of goals. 

Some goals are very specific and tangible, while others are based more on feelings and dynamics between people. 

I broke down my Goals into 7 Types to gain clarity on what exactly I wanted to achieve. Read through them on your dashboard and think about which ones are most relevant to you.
5.snippet: List the goals that you’ve had over the past 5 years, segmenting them by Goal Type.

assignments.content: What are some of your recent goals? Classify them according to the 7 Goal Types.

6.title: What Are the Goals of Others Around Me?
6.subtitle: Phase 1: Meditation
6.description:
Step outside of your own aspirations for a few moments, and genuinely direct your energy towards those around you, be it family, friends or colleagues at work or school. 

Imagine that you have received feedback from your Board of Advisors.  Now it’s your turn to give, and possibly sit on some Boards for other CEO of Mes. What are their goals and dreams, and how can you play a small or large part in supporting them?

While I am a big believer in individuality and self-determination, the big picture puts into perspective the reality that we are all connected and impact each other in very direct and also in- credibly subtle ways. 

This lesson is a call to action for you to open your mind and heart to this truth, and then commit it as a priority in your 20/20 Life Vision. I am sure that you are already doing things to help the goals of others and to help other people.  Some of us are guilty of doing “too much” for others at the expense of our own needs – which is the other end of the pendulum from selfishness, and equally unsustainable. 

There has to be balance in the way you work for your goals versus those of others. Wherever you can find ways to share common goals with others, be it at work or with your family, incredible opportunities for power, human connection and collective achievement exist (e.g., think about a sports team winning a championship, and what the experience they shared, and the life long bonds created as a result).
6.snippet: Climb outside of your own box and consider the goals of others around you.

assignments.content: Who do you really care about (up to 3 people)?
What are their goals (up to 5)? If you aren't sure, ask them.
How do you plan to support them? How much time do you estimate it will require in the coming year?

7.title: What Happens After I Set Goals?
7.subtitle: Phase 1: Mediation
7.description:
This exercise focuses on what usually happens to you after you set goals. Sit down, clear your mind, read this with focus, and answer the questions with clarity. Consider doing this with every exercise.

Doesn’t Goal Setting make you feel inspired and energized? When we set goals, you’re right in that moment of vision. This is the fun part, where you can think freely and have no limits. What typically happens after you set goals however, does not oftentimes transpire the way you planned it. 

Check out the Common Goal Outcomes (CGOs) on your dashboard.
7.snippet: Map out the typical paths that your goals take after you set them.

assignments.content: What are 5 of your goals from the past 5 years?
Classify them according to the 7 Common Goal Outcomes listed below.
Have you noticed any patterns? Have any guesses as to the reasons underlying such patterns?

8.title: What is My Internal Energy Level?
8.subtitle: Phase 1: Meditation
8.description:
This lesson focuses on taking stock of your own energy levels, at different times of the day and week, and then mapping these levels to your daily routines for what I call “Internal Energy Production”. It sounds more like a business term, but it is more relevant to the quality of our lives. Most people simply don’t have enough fuel to effectively pursue their goals and core responsibilities. Even if they do, they are depleted at the end of each day, and enter couch potato mode after getting home from work. 

How often have you thought of or heard others say, “I don’t have the energy to workout. I’m too tired after work.”? The irony is that, although it takes an amount of energy to exercise, what one gets back from that experience is generally a multiple of what was invested.

What are the two most powerful sources of “Internal Energy Production”? 

__1. Physical Exercise__-
There is all kinds of scientific and personal evidence that confirms how important physical exercise is to our moods and productivity. While most agree, it is typically motivation, prioritization or discipline factors that disrupt our best laid plans of integrating exercise into our lives.


__2. Meditation__-

By meditation, I’m not talking about “meditating on ideas” but the act of using our breathe and body to relax, clear the mind and go deeper into our inner worlds. There are so many types and methods of meditation- music, lighting and/or aromas (e.g., incense, candles) and even prayer.
8.snippet: Think about how you produce energy through exercise, meditation etc.

assignments.content: What are your different energy levels (physical, mental and emotional) at different times of a typical day (morning, afternoon, evening)?
(a) How many times do you exercise per week? (b) For how long? (c) What type? (d) Alone or with others? (e) What time of day?
(a) How many times do you meditate per week? (b) For how long? (c) What type ? (d) Alone or with others? (e) What time of day?
Exercise and meditate daily from here on out through the rest of the 20/20 Life Vision Challenge, for at least 20 minutes combined. Are you committed to this? [YES / NO – CHECKBOX]

9.title: Who Are My Role Models?
9.subtitle: Phase 1: Meditation
9.description:
This lesson intends to help you access the depths of your thoughts and feelings, in order to begin the process of drawing out (from your core) your deepest aspirations. What is your life’s purpose? Why have you come here, to Planet Earth, at this point in time, from this family and in this part of the world? With this 20/20 effort, one step at a time, you are creating and refining that vision.

During Step 4, I introduced the concept of being the CEOofMe and building a Board of Advisors, a supporting, positive cast of friends, family, colleagues and mentors. Let’s now consider the influence of a different group – Role Models, Idols or Archetypes. The difference between role models and mentors is that role models can be people that you either don’t know personally, or that you do not have regular contact with. For example, kids idolize movie stars, athletes and celebrities, for various reasons, not all of which are long lasting or necessarily beneficial. Our (Western) society certainly puts a lot of unrealistic and fantastical ideas in our minds, through advertising and other unconscious forms of hero worship. Hopefully, as we grow older, we create more separation between fantasy and reality. Archetypes are role models who are not necessarily who we think they are – after all, how do we really know who someone is from a magazine or TV program?

From where you stand today, who do you consider to be your role models? Hopefully, you have some direct contact with at least one or several people who you really look up to, and seek in some ways to emulate. I recommend identifying or finding at least one role model from your contacts, and then at least one who presents an ideal, that you do not personally know (e.g., maybe someone in your trade that has achieved success). Whose life looks good to you, not just in terms of what they may have materially, but in terms of their inner content, quality of their relationships and their aura – the energy that they give off? Our role models often change as we evolve, moving through different phases of our lives, and therefore, it is OK to “retire” role models, in favor of new ones.
9.snippet: Think about your role models, those who you aspire to be like and can learn from.

assignments.content: Who are your current role models?
What Life Category does he/she primarily influence?
To what degree do you know and interact with each Advisor personally?
Why do you look up to each Advisor? What do you want to learn from them?

List anywhere from 2-10. [Find at least one role model from your contacts and one who presents an ideal in terms of inner content, relationship qualities and energy, that you do not personally know (e.g., maybe someone in your trade that has achieved success).]

10.title: What Does My Internal World Map Look Like?
10.subtitle: Phase 1: Meditation
10.description:
Each of us has a diverse internal world, rich with varying emotions, thoughts and behavior patterns. While we change, hopefully for the better, overtime, many of our patterns are sticky and continue manifesting, possibly taking slightly different new forms. 

In order to develop and attain a meaningful life vision, it is imperative to __“Know Thyself”__ as intimately as possible – or should I say, “Know Thyselves”? Just like any community or family has multiple personalities and voices, that oftentimes want different things, each of us has different aspects of ego-personality within – let’s call those different __“I’s”__, as in “Greedy I”, “Generous I”, “Lazy I”, “Motivated I”, “Obsessive I”, “Calm I”, etc. How well coordinated and integrated those different I’s are, to a large extent, determines how much energy we have, how successful we are in our endeavors, and how good we feel overall. 

You literally have to develop internal leadership skills and claim your rightful place as the CEO of Me, with the understanding that your internal company called “Me” actually consists of hundreds of different “I’s” that all want to be the boss or just do their own thing without accountability to the collective “Me”.

assignments.content: What are 5-15 different Is that you feel are a part of yourself? (e.g., “Lazy I” could resemble “Procrastinating I”)
How strong is each I (1 = Weakest and 10 = Strongest)?
What would this "I" say in a few words (e.g., Angry I – "LEAVE ME ALONE!! STOP BOTHERING ME!”)?
How have each "I" either hindered, aided or done nothing to your goals?

11.title: What is My 5-year Life Plan?
11.subtitle: Phase 2: Assessment
11.description:
Welcome to Phase 2, the Assessment Phase. You will be tasked to look back on the most recent 5 year period of your life and objectively and *honestly* review acheivements, struggles and goal productivity. You'll review areas of your life, from Health and Relationships to Finances.

This is a comprehensive program, and I know that it is not easy to look at yourself in the mirror from all of these different angles, but it is necessary if you want to have a rich and satisfying experience while productively marching forth towards our dreams. The journey is just as, if not more important, than the destination.
11.snippet: Review your goals, goal outcomes and satisfaction with each from over the past 5 years.

assignments.content: What were your top goals over the past 5 years?

Outline the Goal-Setting & Tracking process that you have followed over the past 5 years:
How would you describe your process? [Check off one: A) I haven’t done anything; B) Ad hoc and random; C) Good at setting but not tracking; D) Super detailed and consistent; E) Thorough + working with a coach or peer group]
- Have you written down your goals annually each year? [Check off each year that you have done this for – 2011, 2012, 2013, 2014, 2015]
- Do you use wearable tech, websites and/or spreadsheets to manage your time and goals? [Check one – A) Never; B) Sometimes; C) Often; D) Always]
What main emotions have you felt over the past 5 years?
How far did you get with each goal (as a percentage)?
How satisfied are you with the effort (time & energy) you committed to each goal and the corresponding goal outcome?

12.title: What are My Major Life Events from Over the Past 5 Years?
12.subtitle: Phase 2: Assessment
12.description:
This is a big exercise, and will take different forms over the whole 10 days of Phase 2. Now, challenge yourself to recall your Major Life Events (MLEs) and defining moments over the past 5 years. MLEs specify what happened, whereas Defining Moments determine how you process what happens – what is your internal (energy) and external response? 

Some MLEs to consider include marriage, divorce, graduation, job loss, death, a move etc. Ultimately, what constitutes an MLE for you is somewhat subjective.
12.snippet: Contemplate what your Major Life Events (MLEs) and defining moments were over the past 5 years.

assignments.content: What MLEs happened to you over the past 5 years?
How did those MLEs factor in – positively and negatively – to your goals over the past 5 years?

13.title: Am I Doing What I Love?
13.subtitle: Phase 2: Assessment
13.description:
Over the next 7 steps, I will ask you to assess the last five years of your life, across different core areas:

__1. Career Assessment__ 
2. Financial Assessment
3. Personality & Hobbies Assessment
4. Health Assessment
5. Relationship Assessment
6. Place & Environment Assessment
7. Spirituality Assessment

Reflecting on Step 4 (Supporting Cast or BOA) and Step 9 (Role Models), consider having at least one person, a mentor or peer, to check-in with during the current and upcoming 6 assessments.

The key career question to ask yourself is, “To what degree am I doing what I love?” 90% of people give responses like “I am not sure what I love to do when it comes to work” or “That’s not realistic. I work to make money." What do the other 10% – the ones who are living their dreams – know that the 90% does not? I believe they are purpose-driven people, who have a firm belief that every individual is endowed with certain gifts and skills for a reason and a fulfilling work life depends on whether you put devote your energy to finding and pursuing it. 

Think about the past 5 years, and what type of professional growth you experienced. Think beyond monetary, although money can be a good indicator of your growth.  Are you in the kind of role that allows your best characteristics to flourish? Or do you feel suppressed at work? Are there a handful of new skills that you have attained over this period? How much do you enjoy going to work every day? These questions and more, form the basis of today’s exercise.
13.snippet: Think about your career goals and performance over the past 5 years.

assignments.content: - Has your salary grown (or not) in the past 5 years? [Yes or No]
How much do you love or hate work? (1= Hate it and 10= Love it)

- What does my boss or a peer say about my work performance?
- What do you say, now for myself – what were my shortcomings at work over these 5 years?
- Did you pay a price for your self-recognized or boss/ colleague-perceived weaknesses over the past 5 years?

14.title: Is My Financial House In Order?
14.subtitle: Phase 2: Assessment
14.description:
Who on your BOA relates to your personal finances? Reach out to them for diverse feedback on your relationship with money. What you do with your money can set you up for a life with perpetual debt, or a comfortable nest egg. Money management isn't taught in school. Sometimes, you get lucky and your parents teach you but they are limited by their own relationship with money.

We need to cultivate positive, realistic and balanced views on money, so that we can utilize this form of energy effectively, as a means (not an end) towards achieving our life’s purpose.
14.snippet: Reflect on your relationship with money now and in the past.

assignments.content: What emotions pop up when you think about your relationship with money?

What is your credit score?
Has it changed over the years? If so, how so?

What was your biggest financial achievement over the past 5 years?

What was your biggest disappointment over the past 5 years?

Where do you stand today compared to what you had envisioned for yourself? [A) I am way behind, B) I am a somewhat behind but close C) I am right where I need to be, D) I am a somewhat ahead, E) I am way ahead]

Do you have a balance sheet?
If yes, how does it make you feel?
How does it compare to a balance sheet from previous years?

Do you have a Profit and Loss Statement?
If yes, how does it make you feel?
How does it compare to a balance sheet from previous years?

15.title: What About Me Time?
15.subtitle: Phase 2: Assessment
15.description:
What makes you happy? How do spend "me time"? Personal Aims & Hobbies are any topic or area of your life, aside from Career, Health, Travel, Relationships and Spirituality, that is for you to spend time doing whatever makes you happy – “Me Time”. Watching TV, reading books and learning a language are some examples. 

With how busy life can be, it is very easy– and I will count myself as guilty of this from time to time – to neglect your own needs and interests. Sometimes, you may just need to veg out on the couch, and catch up on our favorite Netflix or HBO series. A life that is go-go-go all the time, is one that I predict is doomed for a crash at some near point. You need to focus some energy on your hobbies to get a break from all the demands being put on you by work, family, society and ourselves! 

One of the key things to consider here is whether or not you are choosing aims and hobbies that boost your energy versus ones that drain energy.
15.snippet: Choose a few activities or hobbies that you enjoy engaging in every month and track how much time you spend on each.

assignments.content:
What activities or hobbies do you typically engage in each month?
- How much time does this hobby take up a month?
- Has this amount of time increased or decreased since Year 1? [Specify Hours per Month per year]
- How does this activity make you feel?
- Do you engage in this activity alone or with others? And if so, with whom generally?

Which of these hobbies, if any, would you be willing to give up if some huge new priority came along, and required more of your time?
- B) Which would you not give up under (almost) any circumstance?

Were there any  aims & hobbies that you weren't able to accomplish that you really wanted to over the past 5 years?
- B) What stopped you from initiating or continuing these hobbies?

16.title: Am I Taking Care of Myself?
16.subtitle: Phase 2: Assessment
16.description:
Health falls right in the middle of the 7 assessments because your personal health truly is central to and connected to every aspect of your life. 

Without your health in order, all the rest of your goals lose meaning and generally cannot be attained or enjoyed. How well are you taking care of yourself? Nobody can do that for you. This exercise will put you- physically – under the microscope.

I welcome one of our health experts – David Owens – to guide this part of the 20/20 journey. David has been in the fitness industry since 2002, is certified as a personal trainer through the Equinox Fitness Training Institute (EFTI), and is certified in Ayurvedic Nutri- tion, GYROTONIC®, and Moral Physics® from the Salas Sommer Institute. He is currently working on the Moral Courage Project with Irshad Manji. David, take it away!

__DAVID OWENS__

“Hi Everyone. Your health is one of those valuable commodities that you may not pay attention to until it is compromised. Learning how to attend to and balance your health needs is a process. As a child, you didn’t come with instructions, but over time, you can develop wellness skills, so that good hygiene and health become second nature and seamlessly integrate into your life. Being healthy impacts all areas of your life and requires your engagement and persistence.

Although a large majority of us may share some common health benchmarks, we all are unique individuals with many factors that determine our health, such as – age, gender, genetics etc. We all have subtle differences.  Don't compare yourself to others. This is YOUR vision and you have to decide what role health plays in your life."
16.snippet: Evaluate the state of your physical health, including your body strength, immunity, and stress levels.

assignments.content:
- How much of a priority was your health over the past 5 years?
- How do you physically healthy do you feel right now? (1 = Not very healthy and 10 = Very healthy)
- Do you think you are a healthy person? [Y/N]

- Do you exercise? If not, why? (Y/N)
- How many times a week?
- What type(s) of exercise do you do?
- What were your top 3 fitness goals from the past 5 years? (B) How would you classify them by the 7 Goal Outcomes?

- What is your typical diet?
- How healthy is your diet? [1 = Not very healthy and 10 = Extremely healthy]
- How many meals do you eat a day? [2 meals, 3 meals, 4 meals, 5 meals, 6 meals, other]
- Do you make your own meals? [Y/N]
- Do you eat organic? [Y/N]
- Do you take supplements? (e.g., vitamins, protein shakes, etc.) [Y/N]
- How often do you over-indulge with emotional eating – by either eating too much or eating junk food excessively? [Daily, 1-2x/wk, Occasionally (1-2x/mo), Rarely, Never]

- How many hours do you typically sleep a night?
- Is that enough? If not, how many hours do you really need?
- What is the quality of your sleep? (1 = Poor and 10 = Excellent)
- Do you have any sleep issues? (Y/N) If so, why?
- What time do you generally go to bed?
- Do you drink coffee or take anything to stay awake or be energized daily?

- What do you do to physically take care yourself (e.g., massage, acupuncture, etc)? How often per month?
- Where in your body do you carry your stress or tension?
- Do you have any notable health issues? How prominent are they in your life? (1 = Very little effect and 10 = A daily challenge)
- How often do you get sick? [# of days sick per year on average, from Year 1 to 5]
- Do you take medications frequently? [Never, Only When Really Sick, Occasionally, Frequently, Daily]

- How stressed out are you throughout a typical week? [1= Totally tranquil and 10= Very nervous]
- How do you deal with stress?
- Are you able to express your emotions in a healthy way? 
- Describe how you communicate your feelings.
- Are you aware of how stressful situations impact your health and life? Give 3 examples.

17.title: How Do I Connect With Others?
17.subtitle: Step 17, Phase 2: Assessment
17.description:
There is no better way to learn about ourselves than through our social relationships. They provide the ultimate mirror, and opportunity to connect with a deeper part of ourselves. In the context of goals, just think about when you achieve something great – you generally want to share it with someone or several people who you are close with. It is also a vital Goal Dimension, I feel – Relationship Quality (RQ) – to our overall happiness in life. 

I’d like to introduce you to one of our relationship experts – Ron Baker – to guide this portion of your 20/20 journey. Ron is an insightful, compassionate and downright profound healer, therapist and guide to thousands of people, including myself, on a 1-1 basis as well as through his books and educational programs. It’s clear that Ron lives true to his purpose on the planet. Ron, welcome aboard and thank you for leading us through this most delicate topic.

__RON BAKER__

"There is so much to say about relationships. It is hard to imagine breaking this topic down in a few paragraphs. Having done 25 years of work with thousands of people around the world, I am convinced that all of your relationships, including the most intimate partners in your lives, are reflections of the relationship you have with yourself.

The most basic determinant of the quality of your relationships is how safe you truly feel to give and receive in mutual value. Typically, when I ask my clients whether they feel safer to give OR receive, the vast majority of people say that they feel much safer giving. I suggest this is because it gives us the illusion of being the one “in control” when we give, followed by a typical experience of feeling vulnerable, exposed and sometimes even unworthy to actually receive. Rather than getting caught up in the psychological reasons WHY we might hold these fears, let’s challenge these limitations in some very simple and nurturing ways that have proved to be safe and effective in so many others’ lives clear ways to make improvements in the quality of your day-to-day.

In closing, I remind you to “be good to YOU.”
17.snippet: Assess the quality of your relationships. Name people who you’ve gotten closer or fell out of touch with.

assignments.content: How do you typically treat yourself? (10 = With tremendous respect and 1 = With almost no respect)
How do you treat yourself during a learning curve, which inevitably involves making mistakes and learning from failures? (1 = Not at all patient and 10 = Very patient)

What do you say to yourself to judge or shame yourself? 
- Who do you truly value?
- How many of these people do you love based on their weight or their waist size?
- How many of these people do you treat with the same contempt and impatience that you do yourself?

How comfortable do you feel giving to others in your daily life?
Do you trust the value of what you have to offer others? (10 = Very Trusting and 1 = Not trustful at all.)

How comfortable do you feel receiving from others in your daily life?
Do you feel worthy and comfortable with compliments or acknowledgments from others? (10 = Very comfortable and 1 = Not comfortable at all)

What were your relationship quality goals over the past 5 years? 
Classify each by Goal Outcomes from Step 7.

Have you been in an intimate, committed relationship over the past 5 years? [YES / NO]
If so, how would you evaluate the quality of the connection and communication, on the whole? [1 = Poor and 10 = Very strong]
Which relationships improved over the past 5 years? With whom?
Which relationships regressed over the past 5 years? With whom?

18.title: Am I In Sync With My Surroundings?
18.subtitle: Phase 2: Assessment
18.description:
I believe, as a facet of our karma and destiny, we come in to this life with a specific vision and purpose.  As we become conscious of this vision, scenarios and environments give us opportunities. Sometimes you move towards that truth through intuitive guidance from elders. Living in tune with nature also tends to align you towards your purpose. 

Regardless of what you believe, there is no denying the power that our environment has on our psyche and productivity. By environment, I mean everything from where you live, who you live with, the water and airquality of your city, what your study, work and rest areas are like, how often you travel to new places, your method of commuting to work and how much time you spend outside, away from technology and closer to nature. 

The goal of this exercise is to make you more aware of the impact of Place & Environment (PE, Goal Type 5) on your own health, happiness and productivity. Over the past 5 years, did you have any PE goals? How much of a priority did you improving or exploring new environmental factors (e.g., moving to a more spacious apartment with more natural sunlight)? 

I feel like a new, and different, more evolved person every time I return from travel.  On the other hand, you can make the “wherever you go, there you are” argument. You can never escape yourself, who you are and what makes you tick.
18.snippet: Get in touch with your surroundings and ask yourself about your connection (culturally, physically, mentally) to the places you currently and have lived.

assignments.content: What changes have taken place in your place and environment since Year 1?

Who do you live with right now?
How does that person influence your lifestyle choices?
Are you truly happy where you are or do you stay there because you are afraid of change (or because this is all you’ve ever known)?

Do you authentically connect to the culture in your town or city? (Y/N)
Are you surrounded by like-minded people? (Y/N)
Are your social needs met in this environment? (Y/N)
Do the climate elements (e.g., humid, dry, rainy, etc.) in your town / city suit you physically and mentally?

What were your place and environment goals since Year 1? 

Classify each by common Goal Outcomes from Step 7.

19.title: Do I Know Who I (Really) Am?
19.subtitle: Phase 2: Assessment
19.description:
God and Love are the two most confusing and complicated subjects to discuss, assess and contemplate for nearly everybody. Have you thought about your Spirituality consciously? Is it part of your daily routine? I bet you'd be surprised how much it touches your life. Emotional health (step 16) and relationship to health (Step 17) are inexticably linked to your spiritual self or rather life philosophy.

In my view, Spirituality entails the following components, and addresses life’s most profound questions:
__1. Purpose__-- Why am I here on Planet Earth? What is my purpose? 
__2. Self-Knowledge__-- Who am I on a deeper level, beyond the human form, race, gender and nationality that I came into being as? 
__3. Karma__-- Why do things happen to me and others in the world as they do (e.g., the good, the bad – wars, crimes, etc)? Is it random or pre-destined? 
__4. Destiny__-- Who is in charge here? Do I have to be compliant with a specific religion or Spiritual path in order to be at peace with myself and be in God’s good graces? Or is God within us, and we get to self-determine our destinies? Or is everything just random? 
__5. Healing__-- How can I feel tranquil and connected to “something beyond myself” on a day-to-day basis? How do I move through and beyond the pain that I have experienced in life?

It will take a lifetime to answer these questions. But start thinking about them now, if you haven't already. All of the sincerest, emotionally strongest and authentically happiest people that I know are those who have placed Spirituality as the #1 priority in their lives. Have you made it a priority?
19.snippet: Think about your spiritual self and what internal qualities of yours have been impacted by spiritual practices.

assignments.content:
What are your current views and feelings about spirituality? What does it mean to you?
Who and what influenced your spiritual views early on in life?
Who are your current role models or mentors in this area? Why do you admire their approach to and views on life?

How much time do you spend each week on spiritual practices, interactions, reading, writing, etc.?
How have your spiritual practices and/or beliefs changed over the past 5 years?

What Internal Qualities (IQ, Goal Type 4) have been influenced – positively or negatively – by your Spiritual practices – or lack thereof?

What insights did you pick up from your spirituality over the past 5 years?

My Purpose on Planet Earth is ....
Beyond my outer form, I am ....
My Karma has shown me ....
Destiny is determined by ....
I have healed emotional wounds from ...

20.title: How would summarize the last 5 years?
20.subtitle: Phase 2: Assessment
20.description:
To gain any technical insights about achieving your Life Vision, you will have to embrace your own numbers and the realities of how much time – and energy – things take to get done.

For now, I ask that you digest what you and others have entered here about the past 5 years.  Then, turn the lens back towards your own life, focusing on the present moment and the next 5 years of your journey.
20.snippet: Conduct a review and reflection report of the past 5 years.

assignments.content: Reflect on your Step 11 entry (The 5-Year Life Report) and make refinements or additional notes. Be more technical and detailed, especially about how you spent your Time & Energy.

Reflect back on your Step 2 entry (More or Less Time) and refine your vision on how you want to spend your time over the next 5 years.

How would you like to ideally break down time across the Pillars of Life?

Reflect back on your 7 Assessments (Steps 13-19): 

Rank each of the 7 Life Categories in order of importance to you over the past 5 years (10= Very Important and 1= Not important at all)

How would you divide your energy and motivation level as a percent of a pie for each Category?

Give yourself a final evaluation for each of the past 5 Years, as well as an overall 5-Year Score (1-10 score per year per Life Category for a total maximum high score of 50/50).

How do your scores compare to the scores others give you per Life Category?

21.title: How Do I Plant & Nurture Seeds?
21.subtitle: Phase 3: Vision Creation
21.description:
Exit Phase 2 – Assessment. Enter Phase 3 – Vision Creation. 

Break out your bucket list! Bring your dreams and Big Hairy Audacious Goals (BHAGs) to the table. Are you ready?

You and others have planted and are continuing to plant seeds in your Garden of Life. Have you assessed your Internal Ecology (to use the phrase of my Spiritual teacher, Dario Salas)? Some seeds will turn into weeds, due to neglect. While others grow beyond your control and imagination, taking on a life of their own. 

Now is the time to assess your Garden and take full ownership of the seeds, weeds and all.

Think Big.
21.snippet: Take an inventory of the seeds that you (and others) planted in your Life Garden.

assignments.content:
Imagine different Life Categories in your life garden. 

Who planted most of the seeds in your garden over the course of your life? 

Are you committed to taking full ownership of your life garden from this point forward?
Reflecting on the 7 Self-assessments ove Steps 13-19, list two Big Hairy Audacious Goals (BHAGs) that you'd like to plant for this next year.

Think about how strong your current tools (e.g., skills, approach, etc) are for tending to your garden. 
What skills do you have? How profient are you in each? (1 = Beginner and 10 = Master) in each.

What level do you aspire to reach in each skill in this next year?

How will you improve those skills?

22.title: What Do I Literally Dream About?
22.subtitle: Phase 3: Vision Creation
22.description:
Let’s tap deeper into your unconscious and draw out your deepest dreams and aspirations for this existence – your life’s purpose.

I’ll start by sharing my story of Jason Stile, who I nicknamed “The Dreamer.”  Jason is one of my best friends and my business partner in the up-and-coming product development company, Ajustco. The key messages that come across are that:  A) Your dreams (and uncon-scious mind) have transformative and illuminating power, B) You can achieve anything that you set your mind to, and  C) No obstacles or setbacks are too great to overcome, when you have sufficient will power.

Check out the this 4 minute video of Jason talking about “the dream” that was the seed (reference: Step 21) for the beautiful, fruit-bearing tree that is now a highly successful company, which continues to grow every day.
22.snippet: Consider your dreams, literally, and envisioned future dreams relating to work, home and your personal life.

assignments.content:
Here are some activities you added on Step 8 [autopopulate those activites]. 

What activities did you engage in today? 

At what time of the time did you engage in them? (e.g., morning, afternoon, tonight)

What do you dream about?
- Any general themes? 
- How often do you remember your dreams? [Choices: (A) Daily, (B) Most of the time, (C) Occasionally, (D) Hardly ever, (E) Never]
- Have your dreams ever come true – as in, you dreamt about something and then it happened? [Y/N] If so, list an instance when that happened. 
- For the remainder of the program [8 Nights of Dreaming], try to remember and write your dreams down first thing in the morning – or even if you wake up in the middle of the night, the way Jason described his experience in the video. Note what themes, characters, settings, fears, hopes and aspirations were present.

In this moment, dream about everything you want your life to be. Anything is possible. Describe what you see.

What are your life dreams?

23.title: What Are My Career Dreams?
23.subtitle: Phase 3: Vision Creation
23.description:
On Step 13, you contemplated to what degree you are doing what you love. In this Step, we flash forward 5 years from now, and the answer is a resounding “YES!!” Think about what needs to be done over the next 5 years in order for that statement to become a reality.

I’ll share some of my own career dreams. In 1996, I graduated from a Columbia College in New York City, where all major banks and consulting firms recruit top “talent” every year, giving them big salaries and putting them on the corporate “fast track” to success. It was the American Dream at work 
– to compete and be on top of the world, in the world’s finance capital, Wall Street! I did what everyone else did – set up interviews and researched these companies, prepared answers to tough questions like a scene from The Devil’s Advocate, The Firm, or Wall Street. I got offers, and considered them.

But, I wasn’t feeling it. The start-up technology world really inspired me. The thought of having to take risks to bring new, innovative products and services to life was exciting. I had an inkling of a vision for my career track, and it didn’t include a big corporation.

So I took a chance by joining my friend, Charles Balsamo, as a co-founder at a small startup called Exeter Technologies. He was CEO and I was CFO, titles we knew little about, but grew into over the next three year. I did all the Sales and Marketing, Research and Development, Human Resources and Finances. It was the building of my foundation and experience in the startup venture world and I loved every minute of it, even the all-nighters, where we had to work around the clock to meet major deadlines. When you really love what you do, it doesn’t feel like work. And that is what I have always sought after. 20 years later, I con-tinue this journey, doing what I love every single day.
23.snippet: cChallenge yourself to think about your career Big Hairy Audacious Goals. Challenge yourself to think about what you really want to do.

assignments.content: Check-In: Have you done your – (A) Mantra, (B) Exercise, and (C) Meditation yet today? If not, now’s the time. [Check Boxes]
If you could change jobs and do something totally new, what would it be?
Reflecting back on exercise 13, what changes would you need to make in your career to increase your fulfillment and motivation levels to 10 (Extremely fufilled/motivated)?
Back on Step 21, you were asked to list your Big Hairy Audacious Goals (BHAGs). Focusing on Career only now, take that a step further by adding 3-5 more Career BHAGs.

Also on Step 21, you thought about the specific skills that you are looking to build over the next 5 years. Go deeper now, with a career focus, what 3-5 career specific skills do you plan to develop?

What specifically will you do in this next year to develop those career-related skills? 
How much time will you dedicate to this professional development (per week)? #Skillbug
The average worker spends 40 hrs * 50 weeks working = 2,000 hours. How many hours will you spend working in 2016? #Workbug

24.title: What are My Money Dreams?
24.subtitle: Phase 3: Vision Creation
24.description:
Now, it’s time to consider how you want your relationship with money to change over the next 5 years. This is not just about how much you have or make – it is about how you think and feel about the world of things, and how skillfully you are able to operate in that world. We’ve all heard the phrase “More Money, More Problems”, a popular lament of the rich and famous, who oftentimes have difficulty with managing money. While we may idolize these celebrities for their stature and seeming access to the finer things in life, how come it seems that many of them are not all that happy? I believe it has to do with two main factors:

__1__- Money may be nice to have, and can surely temporarily help you live a more comfortable and stress-free lifestyle (if managed well), but it does not bring long-lasting joy.

__2__- The energy surrounding money and material things is overwhelming, and attracts many negative forces. Think about the entourages and all-of-a-sudden “friends” that wealthy athletes have after signing big contracts. Everyone lining up for the money train, including financial “advisors”, lawyers and others that “want to help”, causing confusion and These folks did not build a proper Board of Advisors. 

You don’t have to be multi-millionaire celebrities to experience these negative effects. The pure chase for money and things, as well as your insecurities over your financial status, can drain your vital energy, and sabotage positive traits. The trick is to build a positive relationship to the material world, and not let it take over our soul.
24.snippet: Challenge yourself to think about your career Big Hairy Audacious Goals (BHAGs).

assignments.content:
Five years from now, how much money will you have in the bank? 

Who is your “finance team” that helped you not only to attain but also manage your financial success?

What do you plan to do with any excess money that you come into over the next 5 years?

- How will your life differ 5 years from now due to your  money BHAG acheivements?
- How much more or less will you work as a result?
- How many days a year will you take off for vacation?
- What additional material things will you have or have access to that you now don’t?
- what emotions will you feel as a result that you don't feel now?

Who do you want to succeed with or change his / her relationship to money?
How do you want them change his/her financial fortunes in 5 years?
How can you help him/her achieve this goal?

What one wish do you have for the world or a particular sector of the world relating to money?

What group of people or country can be most influential in helping this goal be attained?

How can you help, be it in any small way, to see this goal achieved?

25.title: What are My Personal Dreams?
25.subtitle: Phase 3: Life Vision
25.description:
Are you a person that likes to joke around and laugh a lot? Then, maybe reading comics, watching funny movies, going to comedy clubs or just spending quality time with your best friends who make you laugh needs to be a priority in your busy schedule. If you like to sing, dance and be expressive, maybe a weekly karaoke night, or learning an instrument could be in the cards for next year?

A well-balanced life with core competencies is several areas is generally more fulfilling than one with dysfunctions everywhere. Think about a “successful” business executive, who is at the top of his or her trade but who also travels a lot and works long hours and has poor health and a suffering home life (e.g., A broken marriage, non-relationship with kids and few weekend hobbies/activities).  This person’s energy investment is 65% career with 10/10 fulfillment, 20% personal finances with 9/10 fulfillment and the rest (personal hobbies, health, spirituality etc.) below 3% with low fulfillment levels. 

So with work life and overall life balance in mind, think about what “Me Time” activities and pursuits may give your life that added charm and sense of joy and fulfillment over the coming years. Dream big here and don’t be held back by your inhibitions.  These feats can be built up gradually over the next 5 years.
25.snippet: Think about what “Me Time” activities and pursuits may give your life added charm and a sense of fulfillment over the coming years.

assignments.content:
What activity and hobby goals will you achieve 5 years from now? 
How would you rank these goals in terms of priority? (1= Low priority and 10= High priority)
How many hours per month do you plan to spend, on average, on each personal hobby or activity?
Which areas in your personal time will you cut down on or out completely?

Who you want to see enjoy more time for themselves, doing the things that you know would make them happy? 

How will you help them attain those personal goals 5 years from now?

What's one wish that you have for the world or a particular sector of the world relating to personal aims and hobbies?

How can you help encourage others to help actualize this world goal?

How can you help, be it in any small way, to see this goal be achieved?

26.title: What are My Health Dreams?
26.subtitle: Phase 3: Vision Creation
26.description:
Hello again everyone. It’s David Owens from Step 16. This current Step is usually where you begin to bump up against some of the internal (e.g., inner negative voices) and external (e.g., finding time) obstacles that can prevent you from reaching your goals.  The good news is that, with persistence and creativity all the goals you seek to achieve can be accomplished. You have to be honest and fair though as well. 
 
For example, if you’ve never run long distance in your life, you are potentially setting yourself up for failure if you aspire to run a marathon in one month, and do so in under 3 hours. Set goals that will inspire you to stretch yet that are also within your grasp, and not so challenging that you become discouraged. Also, don’t be afraid to try new things (other than a gym workout) that better fit your persona.  Try tai chi, yoga, Gyrotonic or swimming. 

Remember the basics: 

__Nutrition and Diet__

Though it is cliché – you are what you eat. Being active is very important; but what you eat, the quality of the food, and the quantity are factors if not taken into consideration, can undo all of the hard work you put in. If you don’t like to cook, consider looking into food companies that make healthy prepackaged meals. If you like to cook or want to learn a new skill, the culinary arts are wide open for exploration.

__Sleep__

Sleep hygiene is such a highly under-appreciated component to your health and well-being. Everyone has different requirements for the amount of sleep they need to operate at an optimal level, but the quality of the sleep is just as important. If you consistently need coffee or other stimulants to make it through the day, you’re not getting enough quality sleep. Try out a sleep ritual to help to slumber off. 

__Body Care__

Just like a car, your body needs maintenance and check-ups (not necessarily of the medical doctor kind). Massage, acupuncture and chiropractic adjustments are some of the more pop- ular alternative means of self-care.

__Mental and Emotional Health__

As a complex being, your mental and emotional health are key components to your physical health. Make sure you have someone to talk to, whether it’s a friend or a professional. We need to be heard and understood.
26.snippet: Put away those inner negative voices and accept new ones that launch you into a new, healthier you.

assignments.content:
What changes and achievements will you make across the following areas?
- Prioritizing your Health Goals vs. other Areas
- Fitness & Exercise
- Nutrition & Diet
- Sleep
- Body Care
- Mental & Emotional Health

Who you want to make drastic improvements in their physical health?
How exactly do you want them to change?
How can you help them achieve this goal?

What's one wish that you have for the world or a particular sector of the world relating to Health?

What group of people or country can be most influential in helping to attain this goal?

How can you help, even in a small way, to acheive this goal?

27.title: What are My Relationship Dreams?
27.subtitle: Phase 3: Vision Creation
27.description:
Back on Step 17, you took stock of the current state of your re- lationships. Today, with our resident Relationship Expert – Ron Baker –we take that topic forward into your 20/20 Vision. 

There is no such thing as creating in a vacuum and it is when you come together with others in mutual value that everyone serves the perfect parts of one another’s dreams. Deepening your value of self is integral to valuing and interacting with others in the balance of giving and receiving. 

We live on a planet that has primitive emotional tools and education. However, I witness my clients making major improvements in the quality of their lives, as they learn to reconnect to the emotional and experiential body.

When it comes to relationships, I want to share that I do not believe in magical thinking. I believe that an enhanced reality is built by making a clear investment in the specific goals and experiences that you decide are important in our lives. Whatever you practice the most is what you become best at. And so I hope you will find this exploration of your relationship choices helpful and that you feel encouraged with some specific hints at building a more fulfilling relationship network in your life. I know it is entirely possible, one day at a time.
27.snippet: Challenge yourself to explore your relationship choices and contemplate new ones.

assignments.content:
Take in a deep breath. Then, breathe fully out of the mouth. What does your nervous system think about this receiving and giving of breath?

What old thoughts will you replace with new ones that will create new trust and a new experience? (e.g., Old Thinking = “Missed another workout today. I am so lazy.” vs. New Thinking = “Maybe I’m not getting enough rest. I’m going to take it easy on myself today.").

What will your relationship to self look liin 5 years?

Try to replace habitual negative thinking with daily positive self-acknowledgment by completing the following:

- I am proud of myself for ....
- I feel great that I chose to...
- My gift/talent/ability is ....
What are 3 feelings that you will feel about yourself 5 years from now?
Who are 3 different people you will value or value more than you do now?

What 3 needs (physical, emotional or mental) will you have in your life 5 years from now? 

Are you willing to communicate these needs to another person in the spirit of mutual giving?

What do you want to give more of to others in 5 years? 
What do you want to receive more of from others in 5 years?

28.title: What are my Place & Environment Dreams?
28.subtitle: Phase 3: Vision Creation
28.description:
Contemplate deeply and set your intention on what the ideal surroundings are for you, in terms of your primary residence (country and city), home environment, frequency of travel and day-to-day settings (i.e. exposure to outdoors, nature, pollution, city life, etc). 

It is hard to predict where life is going to “take us”, in terms of new opportunities, people we will meet and places we will have to go in the future. Remember, that we are co-creators in that process, not just beholden to forces that are completely out of our control. This is your chance to set your intention and tap into what life wants from us, and vice versa. Feeling out where you need to be, and what kind of environment is optimal for your happiness and success in life, requires sensitivity and experimentation.
28.snippet: Contemplate and set your intention on what the ideal surroundings are for you.

assignments.content: Check-In: Have you done your – (A) Mantra, (B) Exercise, and (C) Meditation yet today? If not, now’s the time. [Check Boxes]

What major goals [BHAGs] do you envision for yourself 5 years from now? 

What's on your 2020 place and environment bucket list?

How do you rank each bucket list item in terms of priority (1= Low priority and 10= High priority)?

How much time per year (for each of the next 5 years) will you spend, on average, working towards each BHAG and/or bucket list item?

Who in your life do you want to enjoy a major transformation in their place and environment surroundings?
What do you want them to accomplish 5 years from now?
How will you help them make it happen by Year 5?

What’s your place and environment wish for the world or a particular sector of the world?
How can you help, be it in any small way, accomplish this goal?

29.title: What are My Spirituality Dreams?
29.subtitle: Phase 3: Vision Creation
29.description:
Whatever your current level of sensitivity and connectedness to the unseen world is, try to recognize the numerous directional sign posts that life puts along your path. The deeper you go, the more your goals will fall into alignment with the Master plan.

Remember your Board of Advisors, first introduced on Step 4? Good mentors tend to bring everything back to your life purpose and inner journey. There is so much controversy and differences of opinion regarding spiritual philosophy. There are also  a lot of pretenders and predators who don’t have either real knowledge or good intentions, but who prey off of others who are authentically eager and open to guidance. Follow your heart and intuition when it comes to aligning with any type of spiritual teacher or guide.

Today, in building on the mentorship concept, I want to encourage you to consider what other types of support structures you have in your life. It’s not all about having a be-all, end-all mentor, which is not easy to find. 

Sometimes, having peers, who are at or around your same level, can be as helpful as having a mentor; because those people are going through the same challenges as you are can relate.  Ideally, you would have both – guidance from those who have walked in your shoes and moved further along the path, as well as those who are walking the walk, right by your side. Be it a formal support group, or informal group of friends, you really need this type of support . 
Without these support networks, its easier to fall back on bad habits, loneliness, depression and other “negative” emotions. This is the type of overall team that you, as CEOofMe, need to fulfill the deepest ele- ments of your 20/20 Life Vision.
29.snippet: Connect with your larger spirituality master plan and align teachers and guides to help you achieve it.

assignments.content: Who are your spiritual “teammates” in 5 years from now?

What major goals (BHAGs) do you envision for yourself by year 5?

How will you prioritize your list items? (1= Low priority and 10= High priority)

How much time per week do you plan to spend on each spirituality BHAG and/or bucket list item per week?

Remember Step 10 ("Mapping Out Your Internal World")?

How will each of your listed Is (ego aspects) evolve by Year 5? 
What is each I saying in Year 5 that they it didn't now?

Who do you want to enjoy a major transformation or sense of peace and internal happiness in their lives? How will you help him/her? 

How will you want help him/her attain those inner journey goals by Year 5?
How do you want to help further spirituality in the world 5 years from now?

30.title: Your Next 8,760 Hours
30.subtitle: Phase 3: Vision Creation
30.description:
hink back to Step 21’s Lesson (Planting Seeds in Your Life Garden). Think about each hour you have spent on your 20/20 Life Vision as a seed – an idea – that can either grow and bear fruit or stagnate and die.

You will have 43,848 hours over 1,827 days over the next 5 years to evolve and manifest your dreams. The focus now is on building a detailed time and energy allocation plan for a one year – or 365 day – period, thinking in terms of hours (8,760 in a non-leap year). You can also do this exercise at any time during the year, choosing to A) either focus on the remaining days in a given year, or B) focus on a full year that doesn’t correspond exactly to the calendar year (ie. April 2018 – March 2019). Every hour, every minute, every second counts.

With your dreams as guidance and inspiration (Step 22), it is now time to get specific. Make each grain count.

On Step 10, you mapped out your Internal World. Again, I stress the impor-tance of becoming the master or CEO of your internal world, which surely faces hundreds of competing demands. Everyone and everything wants your time and has promises or reasons for why you should spend more time with them. I am asking for some of it here, to participate in this program. Your family wants more of it. Your work and boss want more from you. Community service wants it. The Church wants it. It’s endless. You cannot make everyone totally happy. One of the benefits of this time allocation exercise is to wrestle with these com-peting demands and be firm about what your priorities are. Nothing speaks to your priorities more than how and where you invest your time and energy.
30.snippet: Undergo a time allocation exercise that will force you to wrestle with competing demands. Set priorities about how and where you invest your time and energy.

assignments.content:
Map out the next year of your life - 8,760 hrs (365 days x 24 hrs) according to your Life Categories. Take a cue from Step 2 if needed and multiply by 52 to get your Annual Plan. 

Comment on what you feel most excited about, in terms of what you can get done with that chunk of time. 

What do you most fear?

Spirituality
Core Work
Spirituality
Personal Life
Health and Wellness
Basic Needs
Special Projects

Now, I challenge you to review what you’ve put down in this workbook. What emotions, thoughts or hours jump out to you, and why? Think about what you can do in the now and in the future to harness these features of your past and present life to make positive change in your future life.

Keep planting, evaluating and nurturing seeds in your garden of life! 

Good luck and CONGRATULATIONS!

slides.title: Unveil Your Higher Purpose with...
slides.description: Welcome 20/20 Life Vision Challenge! This app is designed to stimulate contemplation and self-discovery. Expect to gain renewed energy, propelling you into a new life plan. You will review your major goals, strengths, weaknesses, support networks and more! Let’s get started!

slides.title: Vision Creation Advice in the Guidebook

lifevisionapp.io content.title: lifevisionapp.io
lifevisionapp.io content.content:
# 20/20 Life Vision
## A 30-Step Guide to Unveiling Your Higher Purpose
The 2020 Life Vision is packed with practical exercises for anyone seeking to discover, assess and create his or her ideal self! Each exercise focuses a different area of life, including health, relationships, career and finances and is accompanied by expert advice from leading industry professionals.

AppInstructions.title: Not sure where to start?
AppInstructions.content:
## What is this Challenge?

This Challenge will drive you to uncover your true purpose, nurture your gifts and create a more fulfilling life.

Each step is geared for you to gain a new or refreshed and Life Plan. In each step you will be introduced to powerful tools, that will open up new channels of positive Energy and fueling your Life Vision.

## What do I need to know to use it?

The journey is broken down into three phases – Discovery, Self-Assessment and Vision Creation – which are featured in two sections – the Guidebook and Workbook. 


You can jump back and forth between the Guidebook and corresponding Workbook pages (which immediately follow each Step introduction) or read straight through the Guidebook pages and complete the Workbook exercises after.

Focus on the finish line. You can always make changes along the way!
